Comment: This was great fun for me but must have been torture for my poor opponent.  Our grades were much closer at the start of the match, so it's not a case of a simple crushing by a better player, just a case of an unfortunate series of opening errors that were duly punished.
The Scandinavian, or Centre-Counter, is a tricky opening, so both players have to be on the ball.
All standard stuff so far.
All standard stuff so far.
All standard stuff so far.
? but this is not recommended by the books.
Black goes chasing material at the cost of development.
Black goes chasing material at the cost of development.
? Another unnecessary Queen move when all his other pieces are still at home.

The Q is chased away, the B protected and the g-file covered all in one move.
Once again, the Q provides White with a tempo for development.
Once again, the Q provides White with a tempo for development.
This at least prevents castling and again threatens to win material with ...Qxb2
Black is welcome to expend another tempo for the insignificant b-pawn.  White's minor pieces are gaining control of the board.
White completes his development and Black still only has his Queen out.  9 out of Black's first 10 moves have been Queen moves.

and then this non-Queen move is a pawn move that doesn't help develop any pieces.  In fact it deprives the Nb8 of its best square.  While this is a standard move in the Scandinavian, it is usually several moves earlier as part of a plan to preserve the Q.  Now there were far more relevant moves to be made.
White takes aim at the centrally stranded King.
This saves the Q for the time being but deprives King, Bishop and Knight of a useful square.
This saves the Q for the time being but deprives King, Bishop and Knight of a useful square.
This saves the Q for the time being but deprives King, Bishop and Knight of a useful square.
The N takes advantage of the pin on the pawn to attack the Q again.

?! or ?? depending on whether it was deliberate.  Black ignores the attack on the Q and belatedly starts to provide the space to develop his pieces.  Having invested so many tempi in the Q it seems strange to give it up now.  Perhaps it was just a blundering oversight.
White immediately heads for the holes at f6 and d6.
White immediately heads for the holes at f6 and d6.
White immediately heads for the holes at f6 and d6.
Black covers the holes by placing his N on a good square, albeit this is a second move with the one remaining developed piece.
Now the second N reinforces the defence of f6.  It's a pity Black has lost his Q as his pawns look solid but draughty.  White can have a party on the black squares.
Now the second N reinforces the defence of f6.  It's a pity Black has lost his Q as his pawns look solid but draughty.  White can have a party on the black squares.
A mysterious little move.  I'm not sure now why I played it: probably to bolster the d-pawn so that the Q would not be tied to its defence after the inevitable ...Bg7
